title: Use linter for JavaScript
body:
We should use a linter to deal with the increasing amount of code that we have.

Linter will deal with annoying stuff like standard indentation across files.

title: On ruleset details page list related rulesets
body:
On ruleset details page, where user views or edits a ruleset, add an option to view related rules. For the sake of simplicity, call two rulesets related if they share at least one private top-level domain in ruleset targets.

# Algorithm
For each ruleset we can extract list of private top-level domains (sometimes called eTLD+1), using the [Public Suffix List](https://publicsuffix.org/) (sometimes referred to as eTLD). If two rulesets share at least one eTLD+1, we call them related. We can create a table of eTLD construct a VIEW that extracts list of eTLD+1 for each ruleset, then just query it.

# Example
Consider rulesets with targets:
 - Ruleset 1: `example.com`, `www.example.com`, `uk.example.co.uk`
  eTLD+1 list: `example.com`, `example.co.uk`
- Ruleset 2: `cdn.example.com`, `example.net`
   eTLD+1 list: `example.com`, `example.net`

Rulesets are related because they share eTLD+1 `example.com`.

Special cases (we can ignore for now): hosting services with provided sub-domains like GitHub Pages github.io and web.illinois.edu.

title: [META] Ways to speed up database

labels.name: database
labels.description: Everything related to SQL or JS directly interacting with SQL.

body:
These are just some ideas of how to speed up database operations by reducing the number of stored records. There is no real need for this yet.

- Many rulesets contain just trivial rules
  ```
  <rule from="^http:" to="https:" />
  ```
  We might exploit this by storing extra `ENUM ('trivial', 'non-trival', 'both')` in table `rulesets`.

- Many rulesets that contain wildcard targets like `*.example.com` also contain the same domain without wildcard, e.g., `example.com`. We can introduce wildcard syntax that combines both of these, e.g., `[*.]example.com`.

title: Implement ruleset editor

labels.name: UI
labels.description: Everything related to the Web UI

labels.name: database
labels.description: Everything related to SQL or JS directly interacting with SQL.

body:
**This has to be finished before the first demo.**
 - Implement function that converts form to an object aka JSON
 - Send the JSON in a body of the request to the server
    The data should be sent in the request body to handle large rulesets which can not fit into the URL encoding. The URLs have a limited length while some rulesets are tenths of kilobytes large.
 - On the server, update the database
   Also, try to validate the semantic correctness of the ruleset and handle most trivial errors.

title: Limit number of results in a search

labels.name: UI
labels.description: Everything related to the Web UI

labels.name: database
labels.description: Everything related to SQL or JS directly interacting with SQL.

body:
## Problem
If search query is too general, the results might contain too many records, which stalls the server and might even crash Web UI.

## Solution
- Show at most a fixed number of results (e.g., 100).
 - Define a constant on server configuration file and then use `LIMIT ?+1` in queries (e.g., 101 results).
 - If limit is exceeded (e.g., 101 results when maximum is 100), send a message in the JSON indicating the limit was exceeded. Display the message in Web UI..

title: Create our own favicon

labels.name: UI
labels.description: Everything related to the Web UI

body: Replace default [Primer CSS favicon](https://github.com/bershanskiy/https-observatory/blob/master/webui/favicon.png) with our own. Our favicon doesn't need to be perfect, it just should be different from default.

title: On search page add labels indicating the type of ruleset

labels.name: UI
labels.description: Everything related to the Web UI

body:
On the main search page in the result list for each listing add labels indicating type of ruleset. Labels include:
 - `mixedcontent` - display if `mixedcontent: true`
 - `default off` - display if `default off` is set and display details (the string) in a tooltip when user hovers over the label

title: Database closes connection after long periods of inactivity (timeout)

labels.name: database
labels.description: Everything related to SQL or JS directly interacting with SQL.

body:
If database does not get any queries for a long time, it closes the connection automatically.

The timeout intervals are determined via `wait_timeout` and `interactive_timeout` (both in seconds).

## Reproduction steps:
See the timeouts via
```
SHOW VARIABLES WHERE Variable_name = 'wait_timeout';
SHOW VARIABLES WHERE Variable_name = 'interactive_timeout';
```
Currently timeouts are set to 8hours (28800 seconds).

## Possible fixes
 - Change timeout intervals via `SET GLOBAL [variable name] = [variable value]`.
 - Reconnect to database once connection is closed
 - Create a "heartbeat" that regularly pings the database

title: Add ability to log in with GitHub
body:
Use GitHub API to request token allowing us to:
 - create new repository under user's account (to fork HTTPS Everywhere repo)
 - push commits to specific repo (fork of HTTPS Everywhere repo)
 - create pull requests (from user's fork to the official HTTPS Everywhere repo)

This might require change of `users` table to sore relevant information.

title: Store state of the database

labels.name: database
labels.description: Everything related to SQL or JS directly interacting with SQL.

body: Currently Node server just checks for existence of JSON file (`state.json`) and considers database up-to date with `/cache/` if it exists. We should actually store the hash of the commit of HTTPS Everywhere that is loaded into the database and version number of Chrome HSTS preload list.

title: During import database might close connection if the query is too large

labels.name: database
labels.description: Everything related to SQL or JS directly interacting with SQL.

body:
## Reproduction steps
Set the database packet limit to low value:
```
SHOW VARIABLES WHERE Variable_name = 'max_allowed_packet';
SET GLOBAL max_allowed_packet = 4194304
```

On the server force database import:
 - delete `node/database/sate.json`
 - run `node node/server.js`
Observe the output:
```
{ Error: ER_NET_PACKET_TOO_LARGE: Got a packet bigger than 'max_allowed_packet' bytes
    at Query.Sequence._packetToError (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/node_modules/mysql/lib/protocol/sequences/Sequence.js:47:14)
    at Query.ErrorPacket (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/node_modules/mysql/lib/protocol/sequences/Query.js:77:18)
    at Protocol._parsePacket (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/node_modules/mysql/lib/protocol/Protocol.js:278:23)
    at Parser.write (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/node_modules/mysql/lib/protocol/Parser.js:76:12)
    at Protocol.write (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/node_modules/mysql/lib/protocol/Protocol.js:38:16)
    at Socket.<anonymous> (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/node_modules/mysql/lib/Connection.js:91:28)
    at Socket.<anonymous> (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/node_modules/mysql/lib/Connection.js:502:10)
    at emitOne (events.js:116:13)
    at Socket.emit (events.js:211:7)
    at addChunk (_stream_readable.js:263:12)
    --------------------
    at Protocol._enqueue (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/node_modules/mysql/lib/protocol/Protocol.js:144:48)
    at Connection.query (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/node_modules/mysql/lib/Connection.js:200:25)
    at /mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/database/database.js:85:14
    at new Promise (<anonymous>)
    at loadDataHSTS (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/database/database.js:66:9)
    at Object.loadData (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/database/database.js:299:9)
    at main (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/server.js:22:32)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/mnt/d/cs411/https-observatory/node/server.js:137:1)
    at Module._compile (module.js:652:30)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:663:10)
  code: 'ER_NET_PACKET_TOO_LARGE',
  errno: 1153,
  sqlMessage: 'Got a packet bigger than \'max_allowed_packet\' bytes',
  sqlState: '08S01',
  index: 0,
  sql: 'INSER
```

## Solution: Increase the packet limit
Use query 'SET GLOBAL max_allowed_packet = ?' to set the limit sufficiently large for the import.
Refer to this example: [mysqljs /test/integration/connection/test-send-and-receive-large-packets.js](https://github.com/mysqljs/mysql/blob/ad014c82b2cbaf47acae1cc39e5533d3cb6eb882/test/integration/connection/test-send-and-receive-large-packets.js). Note that we might have to close connection and start new one for the change to take effect.

Alternatively, we can break up import into multiple queries.

title: [META] Update Web UI
body:
Search page
  - Add labels to the search results indicating type of content #6 
  - Update information shown on the search results
  - Replace the default favicon with our own #7 
  - Limit number of results in search #8 
  - Display `comment` only if it is not `NULL` or `comment ` is being edited. If comment is `NULL`, let user reveal `comment` field somehow. If user makes the comment `field` empty string, make comment `NULL` and hide the field.
